H0.text: Protecting harmless bacterial cells is achieved when students wash their hands frequently with soap and water, a practice that limits the spread of infectious disease.

H1.text: Changing viral and bacterial nucleic acids is how having students wash their hands frequently with soap and water will limit the spread of infectious disease.

H2.text: Releasing mutated cells from pores is how having students wash their hands frequently with soap and water limits the spread of infectious disease.

H3.text: Removing viruses and bacteria from the skin will limit the spread of infectious disease by having students wash their hands frequently with soap and water.

A4.text: Handwashing with soap is the single most effective and inexpensive way to prevent diarrhea and acute respiratory infections (ARI), as automatic behavior performed in homes, schools, and communities worldwide.

A5.text: According to UNICEF, turning handwashing with soap before eating and after using the toilet into an ingrained habit can save more lives than any single vaccine or medical intervention, cutting deaths from diarrhea by almost half and deaths from acute respiratory infections by one-quarter.
